content:
Pendle Borough Council faces an estimated additional waste bill of approximately £2.6 million from 2026 — representing roughly 20% of the council's entire net revenue budget. The closure of Whinney Hill landfill, combined with the government's new food waste collection mandate, creates a perfect storm for a council already teetering on the edge of financial sustainability.

What Is Changing?

Two major changes are converging to dramatically increase waste costs for all East Lancashire councils:

  1. Whinney Hill landfill closure — Lancashire County Council's Whinney Hill site, which has served as the disposal point for residual waste from East Lancashire, is closing. This means all waste must be transported further, processed differently, or sent to alternative (and more expensive) disposal facilities.
  2. Food waste collection mandate — The central government is requiring all local authorities to introduce separate weekly food waste collections. This requires new vehicles, new bins, new collection rounds, and additional staff — a significant operational and financial undertaking.

Each change alone would represent a major budget pressure. Together, they create what may be the single largest new cost pressure Pendle has faced in a generation.

The Financial Impact

Cost Component Current Cost (Est.) Additional Cost (Est.) New Total (Est.)
Residual waste collection ~£2.8M — ~£2.8M
Recycling collection ~£1.2M — ~£1.2M
Food waste collection (NEW) £0 ~£1.2M-£1.5M ~£1.2M-£1.5M
Additional disposal costs (Whinney Hill closure) Included above ~£1.1M-£1.4M ~£1.1M-£1.4M additional
TOTAL ADDITIONAL COST — ~£2.3M-£2.9M —

The council's own budget documents estimate the additional waste-related costs at approximately £2.6 million. To put this in context:

Metric Figure
Pendle's net revenue budget ~£12-13M
Additional waste costs ~£2.6M
As percentage of net revenue budget ~20%
Existing cumulative budget gap ~£8.26M
Budget gap INCLUDING waste costs ~£10.86M

An additional £2.6 million on top of an existing £8.26 million cumulative budget gap pushes the total projected shortfall to nearly £11 million — close to the council's entire annual budget. For a council whose reserves may be exhausted by 2027/28, this is potentially the pressure that tips the balance from "under severe stress" to "unable to continue functioning."

What Needs to Happen Operationally

Introducing food waste collection is not simply a matter of budget — it requires significant operational changes:

  • New collection vehicles — Specialist food waste collection trucks are needed, typically smaller than standard refuse vehicles
  • New bins for every household — Each home needs an indoor food waste caddy and an outdoor food waste bin
  • New collection rounds — Food waste must be collected weekly (not fortnightly like general waste), requiring additional routes and crew time
  • A food waste transfer/treatment facility — Collected food waste must go somewhere for processing (typically anaerobic digestion). Has a facility been secured?
  • Additional staff — New collection rounds require additional drivers and loaders
  • Resident communication — A comprehensive awareness campaign to ensure residents understand and use the new service correctly

The Whinney Hill Problem

The closure of Whinney Hill landfill affects all East Lancashire districts, not just Pendle. Lancashire County Council, as the waste disposal authority, is responsible for finding alternative disposal arrangements. But the transition creates uncertainty and cost increases for the collection authorities (the district councils).

Key concerns include:

  • Transport costs — If the alternative disposal site is further away, every collection round takes longer and costs more in fuel and driver time
  • Waste transfer stations — Without a local transfer station, collection vehicles may need to travel to distant disposal points, dramatically reducing efficiency
  • Gate fees — The cost per tonne of waste disposal at the new facility may be higher than at Whinney Hill
  • Transition period — Any gap between Whinney Hill closing and alternative arrangements being fully operational could create emergency costs

Cross-Council Comparison

All three East Lancashire councils face the same twin pressures, but their ability to absorb them differs significantly:

Council Est. Additional Waste Cost Net Revenue Budget % of Budget Financial Resilience
Pendle ~£2.6M ~£12-13M ~20% Weakest — reserves near exhaustion
Burnley ~£2.2M ~£14-15M ~15% Under pressure but reserves maintained
Hyndburn ~£2.0M ~£11-12M ~17% Under significant pressure

Pendle faces the largest additional cost as a proportion of its budget, and has the weakest financial reserves to absorb it. This is the council least able to cope with the biggest relative hit.

Government Funding: Will It Be Enough?

The government has indicated that "new burdens" funding will be provided to help councils implement food waste collection. However, experience with previous government mandates suggests that new burdens funding rarely covers the full cost of implementation, and often covers only the initial setup costs rather than ongoing operational expenses.

Key uncertainties include:

  • How much funding will be provided per household?
  • Will it cover capital costs (vehicles, bins) only, or revenue costs (staff, collection rounds) as well?
  • Will funding be ongoing, or a one-off transitional payment?
  • Will rural and semi-rural collection costs (relevant in parts of Pendle) be reflected in the funding formula?

Questions the Council Must Answer

  • Has a waste transfer station been secured? — What arrangements are in place for when Whinney Hill closes? Where will waste go, and at what cost?
  • What are the exact cost projections? — Has the council modelled the full financial impact of both changes? What assumptions underpin the £2.6M estimate?
  • How will food waste collection be funded? — What level of government new burdens funding is anticipated? What is the gap between expected funding and expected costs?
  • What new vehicles are needed? — How many food waste collection vehicles are required? Have they been ordered? What is the lead time?
  • What is the procurement plan for bins? — How many food waste caddies and outdoor bins need to be purchased and distributed? At what cost?
  • What is the staffing plan? — How many additional collection staff are needed? What is the recruitment timeline?
  • How does this interact with the existing budget gap? — The £8.26M cumulative gap does not include the full waste cost increase. What is the combined projection, and what does it mean for reserves?

The Straw That Breaks the Camel's Back?

Individually, any of Pendle's financial challenges — the structural budget gap, the leisure subsidy commitment, the planning service costs, the homelessness cost explosion — would be manageable for a council in a strong financial position. But Pendle is not in a strong financial position. It is a council with declining reserves, an auditor finding of significant weaknesses, and a disclaimer of opinion on its accounts.

Adding a £2.6 million waste cost increase to this picture may be the pressure that makes a Section 114 notice — the formal declaration that the council cannot balance its budget — not just a risk but an inevitability, unless significant savings are found or substantial additional government funding is provided.

Waste collection is a statutory service — the council must provide it. Unlike leisure centres or economic development, it cannot be cut or reduced. This means the £2.6 million must be found from somewhere, and if reserves are already exhausted, that somewhere is other services or a formal declaration of financial failure.

Cost estimates in this article are based on published council budget documents, Lancashire County Council waste strategy papers, and government consultation documents on food waste collection. Actual costs will depend on final disposal arrangements, government funding decisions, and procurement outcomes. Comparative figures for Burnley and Hyndburn are indicative estimates.
